questions.text: A patient with a humeral fracture presents with difficulty extending the elbow and wrist. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Nerves Related to Humerus

Nerve

Location Relative to Humerus

Axillary Nerve (Option D)

Around the surgical neck of the humerus.

Musculocutaneous Nerve

It originates from the lateral cord of the brachial plexus, pierces coracobrachialis, travels between biceps and coracobrachialis.

Radial Nerve  (Option A)

Passes through the spiral groove of the humerus, posterior to the brachial artery, anterior to the long head of triceps.

Median Nerve (Option B)

Passes anterior to the humerus, but does not innervate upper arm muscles.

Ulnar Nerve   (Option C)

Travels down the medial side of the brachium, behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old office worker presents with numbness and tingling in her thumb, index, and middle fingers. The physician taps over the ventral aspect of the wrist, reproducing her symptoms. Which test is the physician likely performing?

A 30-year-old man presents with a laceration to his right wrist after a slash injury. On examination, there is weakness of thumb opposition and numbness over the thenar eminence. Which structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation:
Wrist Slash Injuries

Nerves affected
  • Median nerve
  • Ulnar nerve (less common): Innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (like the hypothenar muscles and lumbricals for the ring and little fingers), and it also provides sensory innervation to the little finger and half of the ring finger. (Option C)

Arteries affected
  • Radial artery
  • Ulnar artery

questions.text: A 30-year-old man sustains an elbow dislocation with a medial epicondyle fracture. He now presents with difficulty flexing the fourth and fifth fingers and an inability to adduct the thumb. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Ulnar nerve (C7, C8 & T1- Root Values)

Muscle

Action

Anterior Forearm
  • Flexor carpi ulnaris
  • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
  • Flexion and adduction of hand at wrist
  • Flexion of distal phalanges.

Hand

Hypothenar muscles
  • Abducts little finger
  • Flexes little finger
  • Pulls fifth metacarpal forward as in cupping the palm
  • 8 Interossei muscles
    • Palmar Interossei
    • Dorsal Interossei
  • Adducts digits 2-5 (Mnemonic PAD)
  • Abduct digits 2-5 (Mnemonic DAB)
  • Assists Lumbricals in MCP flexion and IP extension of digits 2-5

Lumbricals of Digits 4 & 5
  • Flexion of MCP
  • Extension of PIP & DIP joints of digits 4 and 5

Adductor pollicis

Adduction the thumb

Ulnar Nerve Supply:

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent shoulder dislocations presents with a deformity as shown below. On physical examination, the patient is unable to fully protract the scapula when pushing against a wall. Which nerve is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Long Thoracic Nerve

Origin

C5 - C7

Insertion

Serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for scapular protraction and upward rotation.

Nerve actions

(Motor function)
  • Protracts the scapula (pulls it forward around the thorax).
  • Assists in arm anteversion (moving the arm forward).
  • Lifts the ribs, aiding in respiration.
  • Responsible for the anterolateral motion of the scapula, which is necessary for arm elevation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the root value of the nerve that provides sensory innervation in the area marked (X)?
questions.explanation:
Sensory Supply of Arm

Region

Nerve

Derivative of

Root values

Upper medial part

Intercostobrachial

2nd intercostal

T2

Lower medial part

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm

Medial cord of brachial plexus

T1, T2

Upper lateral part

Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm

Axillary nerve

C5, C6

Lower lateral part

Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of arm

Radial nerve

C5, C6

Posterior region

Posterior cutaneous nerve of arm

Radial nerve

C5

questions.text: A 25-year-old male sustains a traumatic shoulder dislocation after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, the patient is unable to abduct his arm beyond 15 degrees and experiences numbness over the lateral shoulder. Which of the following nerve injury is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

A 35-year-old man presents with inability to extend his wrist and fingers. O/E, he exhibits a wrist drop and demonstrates weakness in elbow extension & loss of sensation over the posterior arm and the lateral aspect of the dorsum of the hand. Based on these findings, at which level is the radial nerve likely injured?

options.label: D
options.text: Posterior interosseous nerve at the forearm

questions.explanation:
Location

Causes

Symptoms

Axilla (Option A)

Crutch palsy

Motor Loss:

  • Triceps paralysis (loss of elbow extension)
  • Wrist drop d/t ECRL involvement
  • Finger drop d/t involvement of extensor digitorum
  • Loss of digit extension

Sensory Loss:

  • Posterior arm
  • Lateral part of dorsum of the hand
  • Narrow strip on the back of the forearm

Spiral Groove (Option B)
  • Midshaft humeral fractures
  • Incorrect intramuscular injections
  • Direct pressure (Saturday night palsy).

Motor Loss:

  • Loss of wrist and finger extension (wrist drop & Finger drop).
  • Impaired supination (when the arm is extended).
  • Weakness in elbow extension- partial triceps involvement

Sensory Loss:

  • Limited to a small area between the first and second metacarpals over dorsum of hand.

Elbow (Option C)

(ECRL Preserved)

Supra condylar fracture
  • Finger drop at MCP Joint d/t involvement of extensor digitorum.
  • Loss of extension in the wrist and fingers, but no wrist drop d/t ECRL Preservation.
  • Weakness of supination.
  • Sensory loss at the dorsum 31/2 fingers of the hand

Posterior Interosseous Nerve Entrapment  (Option D)

Radial Tunnel Syndrome: Entrapment of the deep branch of the radial nerve at the elbow.
  • No Wrist Drop: The ECRL remains unaffected.
  • No Sensory Loss: Sensation is intact despite motor deficits.
  • Finger drop at MCP Joint
  • Pain localized over the extensor aspect of the forearm.

questions.text: A patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and index finger. When the examiner attempts to pull the paper away, the patient tries to hold the paper as shown in the image. Based on this observation, which muscle is likely affected?
A 45-year-old musician presents with a noticeable deformity affecting his ring and little fingers as shown in the image. Which muscle is primarily responsible for this deformity?
questions.explanation:
At the Elbow

At the Wrist

Causes: Fracture/dislocation, cubital tunnel syndrome, compression by flexor carpi ulnaris.

Causes: Vulnerable to cuts, and compression in Guyon’s canal.

Symptoms:

  • Atrophy of hypothenar eminence
  • Claw-hand deformity (ring and little fingers)
  • Loss of finger abduction/adduction
  • Sensory loss in the medial hand
  • Positive Froment's sign

Symptoms:

  • Ulnar claw hand
  • Atrophy of hypothenar eminence
  • Loss of finger abduction/adduction
  • Positive Froment's sign

questions.text: A 45-year-old carpenter reports tingling and weakness in his ring and little fingers. Examination reveals hypothenar atrophy and a positive Froment's sign. Which structure is likely compressed?
questions.explanation:
Structures Passing Superficial to the Flexor Retinaculum (medial to lateral)

Structures Passing Deep to the Flexor Retinaculum (through the carpal tunnel)
  • Ulnar Nerve & Artery
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of ulnar nerve
  • Tendon of palmaris longus
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of median nerve
  • Superficial palmar branch of radial artery
  • Tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS)
  • Tendons of flexor digitorum profundus (FDP)
  • Tendon of flexor pollicis longus (FPL)
  • Median nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient struggles to make a fist. When attempting to flex, the index and middle fingers remain straight, while the ring and little fingers flex normally. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Median nerve injury at the wrist

options.label: C
options.text: Median nerve injury at the elbow

questions.correct_answer: C. Median nerve injury at the elbow
questions.explanation:
At the Elbow

Lower Injury (Carpal Tunnel Syndrome)

Causes: Supracondylar fractures, tight tourniquets/entrapment by the pronator teres

Causes: Compression due to tenosynovitis and fractures.

Symptoms:

  • Loss of forearm pronation & weak wrist flexion.
  • Benediction deformity (index and middle fingers remain straight when attempting to make a fist) (Pointing index finger)
    • D/t involvement of FDS & FDP
  • Ape-thumb deformity (flattened thenar eminence, thumb adducted).
  • Sensory loss in the lateral palm and lateral 3½ digits.
  • Weak "OK sign" d/t involvement of FDP & FPL

Symptoms:

  • Burning pain/tingling in Lateral 3½ Digits, especially at night.
  • No sensory loss over the thenar eminence
  • Ape thumb deformity
  • Thenar muscle wasting
  • Can make a fist (Pointing index finger not present)

questions.text: Identify the X correctly from the below image of cubital fossa.
questions.explanation:
Structure Present in the Cubital Fossa

Contents from Medial to Lateral: (Mnemonic: MBBS)

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery division to ulnar and radial artery
  • Biceps brachii tendon
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

questions.text: Which of the following correctly pairs a cutaneous nerve with its corresponding area of supply?
questions.explanation:
Nerve

Cutaneous Supply

Ulnar Nerve

  • The palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial 1½ digits and adjacent palm.
  • Medial side of the dorsum of the hand.

Median Nerve

Lateral 3 ½ digits on the anterior side and 3 ½ nail beds on the posterior side, along with the thenar eminence and the skin over the palm.

Radial Nerve

Lateral & dorsum of the hand, 3 1⁄2 fingers, excluding the nail beds on the back of the hand

questions.text: A patient has a forearm laceration that results in an inability to flex the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers. The affected muscle has dual nerve supply. Identify the muscle injured.

A 46-year-old woman presents with difficulty in thumb abduction and weak opposition. She gives a history of repetitive wrist movements. Which anterior rami nerve roots are likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
From Roots
  • Long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

From Trunks
  • Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Nerve to subclavius (C5, C6)

Lateral Cord
  • Lateral pectoral nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Lateral root of median nerve (C5, C6, C7)
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7)

Medial Cord
  • Medial pectoral nerve (C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (C8, T1)
  • Medial root of median nerve (C8, T1)
  • Ulnar nerve (C7, C8, T1)

Posterior Cord
  • Radial nerve (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1)
  • Axillary nerve (C5, C6)
  • Thoraco-dorsal nerve (C6, C7, C8)
  • Upper subscapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6)

questions.text: Which of the following nerves innervates the muscle indicated below?
questions.explanation:
Median Nerve (C5 to​​ T1- root value) supply of forearm

Muscle

Action

Superficial muscles

(Supplied by Median Nerve itself)

Pronator teres

Pronation of the forearm.
  • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Palmaris longus

Flexion of the wrist.

Flexor digitorum superficialis

Flexion of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints of the fingers.

Deep muscles (supplied by Anterior interosseous nerve)

Flexor digitorum profundus (lateral half)

Flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the index and middle fingers.

Flexor pollicis longus

Flexion of the thumb.

Pronator quadratus

Pronation of the forearm.
